proof: The given conditions imply that the vector $c/\alpha$ satisfies $|c/\alpha|_1 \le k$ and $|c/\alpha|_\infty \le 1$. It is a well-known result that any such vector can be expressed as a convex combination of $\{0,1\}$-vectors, each having at most $k$ entries equal to 1. For every $\{0,1\}$-vector $d$ in this combination, the inequality $\sum_{r \in V} d(r) \text{cost}_C(r) \le \text{cost}_C^k$ holds. By taking the convex combination of these individual inequalities, we obtain $\sum_{r \in V} \frac{c(r)}{\alpha} \text{cost}_C(r) \le \text{cost}_C^k$. This expression is equivalent to the inequality asserted in the statement.
